snippet: Before NASA sends astronauts back to the Moon, it wants to scope out the territory it has largely ignored since the last time it sent astronauts there nearly 40 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Before NASA sends astronauts back to the Moon, it wants to scope out the territory it has largely ignored since the last time it sent astronauts there nearly 40 years ago. The Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter -- scheduled to launch Thursday, although its liftoff may be bumped back a day by the space shuttleEndeavour -- will carry out the first in a series of robotic missions to map and measure the Moon in far greater detail than before. Of particular interest is whether frozen water might lurk in the shadows of craters near the Moon's poles.

headline.main: Orbiter to Map Moon, Looking for Ice and a Home for Astronauts

snippet: In what sounds like the plot of a Bruce Willis movie -- but is in fact a real scientific experiment on a grand scale -- NASA is preparing to plow a satellite and its booster rocket into the surface of the moon on Friday morning.
lead_paragraph: In what sounds like the plot of a Bruce Willis movie -- but is in fact a real scientific experiment on a grand scale -- NASA is preparing to plow a satellite and its booster rocket into the surface of the moon on Friday morning, to see if there is any sign of water in the two dust clouds created by the impacts.
abstract: In what sounds like the plot of a Bruce Willis movie -- but is in fact a real scientific experiment on a grand scale -- NASA is preparing to plow a satellite and its booster rocket into the surface of the moon on Friday morning.

snippet: A piece of a satellite slammed into a Moon crater Friday morning in the hopes of kicking up debris for analysis.
lead_paragraph: Scientists who slammed a bus-size projectile into the Moon on Friday, hitting exactly the spot they were aiming for, say it will take weeks to figure out what they did, and did not, see. More than 230,000 miles from Earth, the Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite hit a bull's-eye -- two, actually -- on the Moon. But the initial images at least, both from the spacecraft and telescopes on Earth, failed to capture expected plumes of debris rising out of the impacts.

headline.main: Two Bull's-Eyes in Test For Water on the Moon

abstract: Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite hits bull's-eye on Moon, but initial images from spacecraft and telescopes on Earth fail to capture expected plumes of debris rising out of impacts; scientists say it will take weeks to figure out what they did, and did not, see; photos (M)

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: LUNAR CRATER OBSERVATION AND SENSING SATELLITE

snippet: The discovery, which came out of a mission a month ago, confirmed scientistsâ€™ suspicions and could help explorers.
lead_paragraph: There is water on the Moon, scientists stated unequivocally on Friday. ''Indeed yes, we found water,'' Anthony Colaprete, the principal investigator for NASA's Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite, said in a news conference. ''And we didn't find just a little bit. We found a significant amount.''

headline.main: Satellite Found Water on Moon, Researchers Say

abstract: Anthony Colaprete, principal investigator for NASA's Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite, says there is water on Moon; scientists hope that water, in form of ice accumulated over billions of years, holds record of solar system's history; satellite crashed into crater near Moon's south pole on Oct 9 and kicked up at least 26 gallons of water (M)

snippet: We're dissing, punting and grousing. We're sussing things out and gussying them up.In other words, we are routinely falling short of the serious, literate, polished tone that we strive for. Instead, we're peppering our prose with slang and...
lead_paragraph: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style.
abstract: We're dissing, punting and grousing. We're sussing things out and gussying them up.In other words, we are routinely falling short of the serious, literate, polished tone that we strive for. Instead, we're peppering our prose with slang and colloquialisms, often of the most trite and tired variety.
